podcast_details.episode_transcript: Hey, it's Steve Paulson and this is Luminous, a podcast series about psychedelics from To the Best of Our Knowledge. It might just last a few days or a few weeks. So it's really important to understand this critical period when our minds are so open and also so vulnerable. These critical periods are what Gule Dolan has been studying for years. Yeah, she's given MDMA to octopuses. She's also challenging a lot of the scientific work that's been done on psychedelics. She has serious doubts about the value of neuroimaging or even a concept like the default mode network. And that was overwhelming for me and I really haven't let go of my amazement at that ever since. Yeah, so my interest in pro-social behavior, social behaviors really actually also goes back to those early college days where I was trying to understand philosophical concepts like theory of mind and the relationship for that being able to understand the world from another person's perspective. And then years later when I started my own lab, we discovered a novel critical period for social behavior and I'll explain what critical periods are in a second. I could use that to try and understand what are the mechanisms underlying this critical period and can we use this drug to reopen them? What MDMA does is it binds to that transporter and actually reverses the direction of it. So instead of vacuuming up serotonin, now it's extruding serotonin in massive quantities into the synapse. And when that happens, it seems to trigger the release of oxytocin, which is another neurotransmitter that has been heavily implicated in social behaviors. And so when we first started working on MDMA, that's what we thought the story was. We thought it was all about serotonin and oxytocin and that we could account for all of its therapeutic actions, all of its ability to reopen this critical period was all based on that mechanism. You have done a lot of the pioneering work on this idea of a critical period, especially after a psychedelic experience. Can you explain what this is and why it's so important? Yeah. So neuroscientists, independent of psychedelics, have been obsessed with the idea of critical periods for almost 100 years. Ever since they were discovered in 1935, three Nobel prizes have been given. Neuroscientists want to figure out about critical periods. podcast_summary: In this episode of the Luminous podcast, neuroscientist Gule Dolan discusses the neuroscience of critical periods in relation to psychedelics. She explains how psychedelics have a unique capacity to open up the mind and increase plasticity, allowing for new perspectives and possibilities. Dolan's groundbreaking studies on critical periods and her work with octopuses demonstrate the potential of psychedelics in therapy. The podcast also challenges popular theories, such as the default mode network, and highlights the importance of understanding and supporting individuals in the vulnerable and open state that follows a psychedelic experience. #psychedelics #neuroscience #criticalperiods #therapy #plasticity
podcast_highlights:
Highlight 1: Critical Periods (00:58 - 13:45)

Neuroscientist Gule Dolan discusses the concept of critical periods, which are windows of time when the brain is especially sensitive to learning and memory formation. Dolan explains that psychedelics have the ability to reopen these critical periods and allow for new patterns of thinking and behavior to form. This insight challenges the belief that critical periods are only relevant in childhood and suggests that psychedelics may have therapeutic potential for adults.

Highlight 2: Mechanisms of Critical Period Reopening (25:14 - 36:44)

Dolan explores the mechanisms by which psychedelics reopen critical periods. She describes three main processes involved: remodeling of the extracellular matrix, metaplasticity (changes in synaptic plasticity induction), and changes in inhibitory-excitatory balance. By studying these mechanisms, researchers can gain a better understanding of how psychedelics impact the brain and facilitate transformative experiences.

Highlight 3: Risks and Benefits of Psychedelic Use (47:20 - 55:01)

Dolan discusses the potential risks and benefits of using psychedelics during critical periods. While psychedelics have shown promise in treating mental health conditions and facilitating personal growth, Dolan emphasizes the importance of providing individuals with a safe and supportive context during their psychedelic experiences. She also expresses concerns about the medicalization of psychedelics and the need for further research to mitigate risks and optimize therapeutic outcomes.
